I've been trying to filter out the use of the utils.parseTimestampQueryParam, utils.parseAccountIdQueryParam, utils.parseBalanceQueryParam , utils.parseLimitAndOrderParams and utils.parsePublicKeyQueryParam.
It's older logic that accounts, balances and transactions endpoints established. Each method ends up puling all the query items form the request then pulling out the desired query and verifying it.
I've been trying to move to

Pulling out all query items once using const filters = utils.buildFilterObject(req.query);
Verifying them all at once using utils.validateAndParseFilters(filters);
Building the sql query with logic similar to extractSqlFromTokenRequest

It would be great if we can conform to that.
I'm hoping in a future backlog PR to rip out the aforementioned ones in favor of this.
changed it to the new workflow

I know having addToken and addAccount call addEntity makes for less code but I think it also results in having the spec objects define objects similar to the proto objects that don't equate to a importer domain object.
I believe the intent on the spec setup objects was to have a 1:1 object representation of a row in an existing table.
In that sense we should keep the current logic and specify an entity and a token object when adding a token.
As future entities that differ from accounts are added they are likely to be like token and require extra properties not found int he t_entities table.
Furthermore, this supports testing scenarios where a token row exists but say the entity row is missing.

Just reverted and created a new section 'entities' instead of reusing 'accounts' for the purpose of adding 'tokens' into the entities table.
Data presented at protobuf level has better readability and less error-prone since duplication is reduced. If needed, we can address it later.

I saw this too.
Ended up doing fs.mkdirSync(flywayDataPath, {recursive: true}); but this works too

Interesting. i think the way the {recursive: true} works is because internally it recursively checks if every folder is created from the top level of path: if the folder exists, it just skips it so no error thrown. which works for our purpose!

nit: I think we should just have this as tokenId like we have with topicId.
I don't think we want to keep the x.y naming convention used by accounts
changed to tokenId as suggested

This should be the publickey of the token entity not the account entity.
If a user wants to filter by the account public key for balances they would just use the /balances endpoint currently.
However, this brings up maybe a feature enhancement of adding filtering by publickey for both token and account entities.
For now we should do token, you can always create a Feature request for account.
As coded is correct.
According to the design doc this should only contain id, balance, timestamp and publickey
Where id and publicKey are those of the token entity not the account entity
id and publicKey are defined correctly as for the token. However, this map should contain all the applicable query filters (excluding order and limit) for this endpoint similar to filterColumnMap
clarified how the tokenBalancesFilterColumnMap in the other conversation

You'd want to have this check first to make sure all cases processed are allowed queries.
For instance timestamp is working but is not in the list of tokenBalancesFilterColumnMap

this is done intentionally, the map is for generic filter handling while timestamp and public key can't be done that way, so the two are handled by its own case branch;
on the other hand, even the two are in the map, the map & the following !columnKey won't get hit

See extractSqlFromTokenRequest, it's able to use filterColumnMap to ensure only those filter queries in addition to order and limit are processed.
If the current logic works better for your query that fine, we should just make sure no additional query filters pass through, only those explicitly stated

the implementation does exactly what you described:

we should just make sure no additional query filters pass through, only those explicitly stated

The difference compared to extractSqlFromTokenRequest and filterColumnMap is that timestamp and publickey for token balances need special handling, just like limit and order so their handling is promoted to individual case branches, not the generic default branch.
So in other words, because the way the filters from the token balances REST GET query go into the SQL query is different than token discovery:

timestamp needs a subquery and the eq query operator (or the = operator after parsing) needs to be overridden to <=
the account's publickey query param is reflected as a condition in the entity join clause, not the top level where clause, for performance consideration

As a result, timestamp and publickey in token supply distribution indeed are not generic filters which go into the top level where clause by simply appending AND ${key} ${op} ${value}, thus they should not appear in tokenBalancesFilterColumnMap

nodes.bodyText:
in the previous PR which adds token balances to balances API, I changed token_balance__pk to
token_balance__pk primary key (consensus_timestamp, account_id, token_id)
because the queries are all first on consensus_timestamp then account_id
For token supply distribution, it's first on consensus_timestamp then token_id so the new index is needed.

nodes.bodyText: I see, but I'm not sure if this index will speed things up much in comparison to just using the token_balance__pk. The leading column in a b-tree multi-column index is the only column that reduces the number of index entries that are scanned and accounts for the majority of the speed improvements. I'm worried about the memory and write performance impact of this index.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,3 @@
+-- Add index for query by consensus_timestamp followed by token_id
+create index if not exists token_balance__timestamp_token_account

nodes.bodyText:
The index can speed up queries when there are many tokens or some tokens are associated with many accounts. For token balances query, both consensus_timestamp and token_id are with equality constraints, with the new index, I think both are taken into consideration to limit the index scan range. So when there are many tokens or some tokens are associated with many accounts, the new index should provide better performance.
Perhaps, we can drop it now and consider it when token utilization is high and the read performance improvement outweighs the write performance impact?
